rounds.response:
Turn 1 – I have an early read on relative values.

Brick (30 value) and Ore (40 value) are clearly my most precious resources; Sheep (12) are least valuable to me, Wood/Wheat sit in between. I need to turn surplus into value without giving away my scarce heavyweights.

Looking at the table I suspect Wheat/Wood are more useful to me for building flexibility, so I can afford to give some Ore for the right mix—but only sparingly.

I open the dialogue:

[Offer: 2 Sheep, 1 Wheat -> 2 Wood, 1 Brick]

rounds.response:
Alright, getting rejected on sheep screams “they don’t value sheep as highly as my own sheet says” – so the simplest fix is to swap the sheep into something they still need but that I’m less dug in about. Ore and brick are my high-per-unit goods (40 & 30), while wood is still modest (8) and wheat is clearly lowest (6). Offering pure Ore or Brick would hurt me badly, but mixing one lower-valued item with a single high one could entice them without killing my score.

The most effective swing with minimal pain would be reallocating one brick (I have 22, an ample buffer) to score what they let slip last time (the 2 wood, 1 brick). I don’t throw sheep this round since they clearly balked at them.

[Offer: 1 Brick, 2 Wheat -> 3 Wood]

rounds.response:
Turn 5 – Player 0

I pause to reassess.

Score impact of the rejected offers  
– My last proposal (1 Brick + 2 Wheat → 3 Wood) would have lowered my total value by 4 pts but was rejected anyway, so nothing lost.  
– Player 1 is extremely passive: he has countered zero proposals and initiated none of his own.

Strategic insight  
My Brick is my most over-weight resource (22 qty × 30 pts), while Wood is my scarcest (18 qty × 8 pts). Every Brick I can turn into Wood/Silver equivalent (even if unit-for-unit below Brick’s 30 value) ratchets up my *quantity* of scarce Wood, which in multiplayer endgames usually decides tiebreakers and builds.

Fresh offer  
I sweeten the prior package to give Player 1 an incentive without overdiluting my upper-priced Ore.

[Offer: 3 Brick -> 7 Wood]

rounds.response:
Let me quickly recalculate my current total value so I stay oriented.

Totals worth at Turn 4  
Brick: 22 × 30 = 660  
Ore:   19 × 40 = 760  
Sheep: 11 × 12 = 132  
Wood:  18 × 8  = 144  
Wheat: 20 × 6 = 120  
Current stock value = 1 816

---

### Analyse P1’s counter-proposal

P1 offers me: 3 Ore (120 value) + 1 Wheat (6) = 126 worth  
P1 wants from me: 10 Sheep (12 each) = 120 worth  

• It’s a 6-point net gain (126 – 120).  
• However, Ore is already my highest-value resource (I lose practical diversification if I replace 10 Sheep with an extra 3 Ore).  Currently I have 19 Ore, so the increment is small.  
• Post-trade I would hold only 1 Sheep total, effectively removing that entire category from future interactions and reducing flex room.  
• Value edge is trivial (-6 net when you factor Ore’s market-implied value vs. list price).  

Therefore the upside is minimal and the strategic downside (losing all Sheep) outweighs it.

[Deny]

---

### Most advantageous next move

I’d like to pick up cheap Wood and Wheat without touching my Ore cache. I’ll offer a Bricks-for-Wood package that slightly favours P1 on raw list price but gives me resources I actually need.

[Offer: 3 Brick -> 9 Wood]

rounds.response:
Round-tripper view of our stash so far  
- Value surplus from round-0 start: -6.6 (the three bad early offers I floated all lost value)  
- Our best single resource upside is still Ore (40), but we are heavy on Brick (22) and light on Wood (18).  
- Opponent has said “no” to every swap that gives them the cheaper Brick; that confirms they value Wood/Ship rather highly.

The single fastest way to push your net-worth ahead in the next 3 turns is to turn excess Brick into high-value Ore and/or fill the Wood gap without giving Ore away.  Let’s test that in a one-shot offer that should look very attractive on paper to Player 1 (they can’t normally acquire 5 cheap Brick in one bite).

[Offer: 5 Brick -> 2 Ore, 3 Wood]

rounds.response:
Let’s take stock of what has happened, the market values, and where the advantages lie.

Current reserves  
   Wheat 20 @ 6  
   Wood   18 @ 8  
   Sheep 11 @ 12  
   Brick 22 @ 30 (biggest stockpile)  
   Ore   19 @ 40 (highest-value unit)

Key facts from the log  
- Early on we tried to shift surplus Brick/Wood for the scarcer Wood and Ore but were rejected.  
- P1 just offered: their 4 Wood + 2 Sheep for our 3 Brick + 1 Ore.  
  Net value to us: we lose 3×30 + 1×40 = 130 and gain 4×8 + 2×12 = 56 → –74 value, an awful trade.  
- P1 clearly wants Brick (most plentiful and mid-tier value) but is undervaluing their Wood/Sheep to an extreme.

With six turns left the game, our overriding goal is simple: convert surplus low-marginal-value goods (especially Brick) into high-marginal-value Wood and Ore while accepting as little premium-over-market as possible.

Hence the counter-proposal—keep it modest so it may actually land, yet still strictly neutral-to-favorable:

[Offer: 2 Brick -> 4 Wood, 1 Sheep]

Valuation: we lose 2×30 = 60, gain 4×8 + 1×12 = 44. The 16-value gap vs. P1’s last offer shrinks the spread appreciably but remains tilted away from us. If P1 truly values Brick highly, this might be the maximum we can capture without overpaying.

0.reason: Same change in inventory value for all players. Draw.

1.reason: Same change in inventory value for all players. Draw.
